definition: a woman who has power, authority, or ownership: such as
the female head of a household
a woman who employs or supervises servants
examples: The servants were required to do their mistress's bidding without question.

definition: a woman who possesses, owns, or controls something
examples: the mistress of a large fortune
Whether mongrels or thoroughbreds … dogs have shared their masters' and mistresses' experiences in almost all walks of life.

definition: a woman who is in charge of a school or other establishment : headmistress
examples: Mrs. Goddard was the mistress of a school

definition: a woman of the Scottish nobility having a status comparable to that of a master (see master sense 3b)
a woman who has achieved mastery in some field
examples: She was a mistress of music.
You learn how to chop throats and gouge eyes and stomp insteps … and after eight weeks you're given your diploma, which officially declares you a mistress of unarmed combat.

definition: a woman considered especially notable for something
examples: After penning several apocalyptic books, she became known as the mistress of doom.

definition: something personified as female that rules, directs, or dominates
examples: … France was master of the Continent, England mistress of the seas.
Yet he was sharp and self-interested enough (serving, that is, his demanding mistress, Painting) to write more than 400 letters …

definition: a woman other than his wife with whom a married man has a continuing sexual relationship
used archaically as a title prefixed to the name of a married or unmarried woman
used as a conventional title of courtesy except when usage requires the substitution of a title of rank or an honorific or professional title before a married woman's surname mrs. sense 1a

examples: With each addition of pain or restraint, he stiffens slightly, then falls into a deeper calm, a deeper peace, waiting to obey his mistress.
